elements.content: A novel Cu­(I)-based two-dimensional (2D, 44 net) metal–organic framework (MOF) [Cu­(L)­(I)]2n ·2nDMF·nMeCN (1); L = 4′-(4-methoxyphenyl)-4,2′:6′,4″-terpyridine; DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide, MeCN = acetonitrile) has been synthesized and found to behave as a colorimetric detector for the widest variety of small molecules such as different solvents, halobenzenes, N-heterocycles, amine, and nitroaromatic explosives all in vapor phase through a single crystal to single crystal (SCSC) transformation. The 2D 44 nets are interdigitated with each other to form a supramolecular 3D MOF having 1D pore. The interdigitated layers are stabilized by π···π interactions and CH···π interactions and provide extreme stability up to 380 °C. Interestingly, all guest exchange and encapsulation processes are reversible without loss of structural integrity. Positions of the guest molecules in the host–guest complex have been identified from the crystal structure and found to involve weak interactions with the framework. Notably, this is the first time for a report of any material which encapsulates such a large number of small molecules in the vapor phase from different chemical classes in SCSC fashion with visible color changes. Tests confirm the selectivity toward most polar molecule in a class. In the presence of guest molecules, the MOF exhibits a blue shift in fluorescence emission spectra and the extent of the blue shift is appreciably high. It also shows high selectivity toward diethylamine (dea) among N-heterocycles, amine, and highly explosive trinitrophenol (TNP) among nitroaromatic explosives as revealed from concurrent luminescence quenching in solution. Finally, the MOF represents one of the best hosts reported so far having extreme stability and selectivity and meets the benchmark of reversibility for material applications.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have received considerable scientific attention in the past 2 decades for their potential applications in sensing, gas storage and separation, proton conduction, magnetism, and catalysis, etc. For developing a storage material the decisive task is to make the adsorption and desorption process reversible without any permanent structural changes in the molecule, whereas, for developing sensor materials, the challenge is to rationalize signal transduction, that is, in the presence of an analyte the material should exhibit distinct and easily detectable changes in the properties such as color, refractive index, redox potential, and luminescence, etc. In most of the MOF-based sensors, the signal processing employed luminescence quenching or enhancement due to the presence of certain analytes on the surface or in the pores. Another and maybe the most convenient way of detection or sensing is the certain shift of optical absorption bands in the visible region in the presence of analytes. This means the presence of a solvent or any other guest can be confirmed by a visible color change of the solid material, and the phenomena is known as solvatochromism when the guest is a solvent. Recently, a series of isostructural Cd­(II)-MOFs have been reported that are capable of adsorption and separation of toxic halogenated aromatics at room temperature (RT) in the liquid phase. Few groups have reported wonderful application of luminescent MOFs for fast and reversible detection of nitroaromatic derivatives and other explosives in vapor stage. Three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular frameworks featuring 1D nanocoordination spaces have also been exploited for molecular recognition. However, none of the examples demonstrate selective and reversible detection of more than one substance in a SCSC fashion without change in structural integrity. In this work, a unique 3D supramolecular luminescent MOF {[Cu­(L)­(I)]2n ·2nDMF·nMeCN} (1) employing a V-shaped flexible terpyridine-based ligand L (L = 4′-(4-methoxyphenyl)-4,2′:6′,4″-terpyridine) as linkers and Cu2I2 cluster as nodes has been synthesized () that shows guest exchange and encapsulation of a variety of solvents, toxic monohalobenzenes, N-heterocycles, amine, and explosive nitroaromatic vapors in an SCSC manner with unique color changes and without change in structural integrity. All of the guest exchanged complexes are characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD), elemental analysis (EA), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) ( Figures S1–S8). TGA demonstrates the thermal stability of the complex up to ∼380 °C, the PXRD pattern reveals bulk phase purity, and EA confirms the elemental composition of the solvent exchanged complexes. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report on a material among all known similar classes of materials that behaves as a universal encapsulator and visual colorimetric detector for such a wide variety of chemical substances.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have received considerable scientific attention in the past 2 decades for their potential applications in sensing, gas storage and separation, proton conduction, magnetism, and catalysis, etc. For developing a storage material the decisive task is to make the adsorption and desorption process reversible without any permanent structural changes in the molecule, whereas, for developing sensor materials, the challenge is to rationalize signal transduction, that is, in the presence of an analyte the material should exhibit distinct and easily detectable changes in the properties such as color, refractive index, redox potential, and luminescence, etc. In most of the MOF-based sensors, the signal processing employed luminescence quenching or enhancement due to the presence of certain analytes on the surface or in the pores. Another and maybe the most convenient way of detection or sensing is the certain shift of optical absorption bands in the visible region in the presence of analytes. This means the presence of a solvent or any other guest can be confirmed by a visible color change of the solid material, and the phenomena is known as solvatochromism when the guest is a solvent. Recently, a series of isostructural Cd(II)-MOFs have been reported that are capable of adsorption and separation of toxic halogenated aromatics at room temperature (RT) in the liquid phase. Few groups have reported wonderful application of luminescent MOFs for fast and reversible detection of nitroaromatic derivatives and other explosives in vapor stage. Three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular frameworks featuring 1D nanocoordination spaces have also been exploited for molecular recognition. However, none of the examples demonstrate selective and reversible detection of more than one substance in a SCSC fashion without change in structural integrity. In this work, a unique 3D supramolecular luminescent MOF {[Cu(L)(I)]2n ⋅2nDMF⋅nMeCN} (1) employing a V-shaped flexible terpyridine-based ligand L (L = 4'-(4-methoxyphenyl)-4,2':6',4"-terpyridine) as linkers and Cu2I2 cluster as nodes has been synthesized () that shows guest exchange and encapsulation of a variety of solvents, toxic monohalobenzenes, N-heterocycles, amine, and explosive nitroaromatic vapors in an SCSC manner with unique color changes and without change in structural integrity. All of the guest exchanged complexes are characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD), elemental analysis (EA), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) ( Figures S1-S8). TGA demonstrates the thermal stability of the complex up to ~380 °C, the PXRD pattern reveals bulk phase purity, and EA confirms the elemental composition of the solvent exchanged complexes. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report on a material among all known similar classes of materials that behaves as a universal encapsulator and visual colorimetric detector for such a wide variety of chemical substances.

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic data were collected at 130 K on a Brüker Smart Apex II CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. Data collection was performed using φ and ω scans. The structures were solved using direct method followed by full-matrix least-squares refinements against F2 (all data HKLF 4 format) using the SHELXTL2 software package. Anisotropic refinement was used for all non-hydrogen atoms. The crystal data of all complexes were collected at low temperature (130 K), but in most cases the thermal displacement parameters of the atoms of the guest/solvent molecules inside the framework pores were larger than expected. This could arise from an unresolved positional disorder or from the fact that the fraction of pores occupied by guest molecules is less than 100%. Another possible reason could be the solvent loss which is a characteristic of open pore coordination polymers. This slight, nonuniform process would contribute to a poor statistical agreement between equivalent reflections collected at different times. This results in extremely weak data and contributed to the overall poor data quality, and the use of extensive geometric and thermal displacement parameter constraints (EADP and DELU) for the guest/solvent molecules to keep the refinement stable became a necessity. These were mostly used to maintain reasonable aromatic ring geometry of the guest molecules in Ph–F, Ph–Cl, Ph–Br, dea, trz, and NB in complexes 1e, 1f, 1g, 1i, 1j, and 1l ().
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Single-Crystal Structure Determination

X-ray crystallographic data were collected at 130 K on a Brüker Smart Apex II CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. Data collection was performed using φ and ω scans. The structures were solved using direct method followed by full-matrix least-squares refinements against F2 (all data HKLF 4 format) using the SHELXTL2 software package. Anisotropic refinement was used for all non-hydrogen atoms. The crystal data of all complexes were collected at low temperature (130 K), but in most cases the thermal displacement parameters of the atoms of the guest/solvent molecules inside the framework pores were larger than expected. This could arise from an unresolved positional disorder or from the fact that the fraction of pores occupied by guest molecules is less than 100%. Another possible reason could be the solvent loss which is a characteristic of open pore coordination polymers. This slight, nonuniform process would contribute to a poor statistical agreement between equivalent reflections collected at different times. This results in extremely weak data and contributed to the overall poor data quality, and the use of extensive geometric and thermal displacement parameter constraints (EADP and DELU) for the guest/solvent molecules to keep the refinement stable became a necessity. These were mostly used to maintain reasonable aromatic ring geometry of the guest molecules in Ph-F, Ph-Cl, Ph-Br, dea, trz, and NB in complexes 1e, 1f, 1g, 1i, 1j, and 1l ().

The final thermal temperature factors indicate that the guest/solvent molecules in the MOFs are severely disordered and most of the alert level “A” and “B” arise due to the high thermal displacement parameters. The aromatic rings in Ph–F, Ph–Cl, Ph–Br, and NB were refined as rigid hexagons using AFIX 66 to stabilize the refinement (). A full anisotropic refinement was not possible for complex 1 due to the diminished data quality caused by weak diffraction (). The C36 of acetonitrile was left isotropic to keep the refinement stable.

elements.content: CuI was chosen as a precursor for its diverse photophysical properties, so it was expected to show guest responsive luminescence properties. SCXRD analysis ( Tables S1–S3) reveals that 1 crystallizes in a monoclinic system with C2/c space group. Each Cu­(I) center in 1 is coordinated by N atoms of two ligands (L) and two iodide ions resulting a distorted tetrahedral geometry ( Figure S9). The measured Cu–N distance is 2.020(7) Å, and Cu–I distances are 2.664(1) and 2.669(1) Å, respectively. The bond angles around the Cu­(I) center lies in the range of 100.70(5)–121.75(5)°. The distortion from the regular tetrahedral geometry can be described by an angular index (τ4), which was defined by Houser and co-workers as follows: τ4 = [360 – (a + b)]/141 (a and b are the two largest angles around a four-coordinate metal center). Since, in 1, the calculated τ4 = 0.87, the coordination geometry around the Cu­(I) center can be best described as trigonal pyramidal. Besides, it exhibits a rhomboidal Cu2I2 core, which can be termed as a secondary building unit (SBU; a). The repetition of the [(CuI)2(L)2] units give rise to an extended 2D 44 (brick-like) net ( Figure S10). In the Cu2I2 core, the Cu···Cu distance is 2.596(2) Å and Cu–I–Cu and I–Cu–I bond angles are 58.24(4)° and 121.75(5)°, respectively. Interestingly, four rhomboidal Cu2I2 units are connected through four ligands to form a [4 + 4] metallamacrocylic unit ( Figure S11), and the distances between the centroid of the Cu2I2 units connected by ligand L are in the range of 13.332–13.479 Å. Further, the 2D 44 nets are interdigitated (c) with each other to form a supramolecular 3D MOF (d). The interdigitated layers are stabilized by π···π interactions among the pyridyl rings of L and CH···π interaction between methoxy group and pyridyl ring of L (). Complex 1 also exhibits rectangular voids of dimension 7.67 Å × 9.18 Å down the c-axis ( Figure S12). Detailed study of one rectangular void reveals the presence of a 1D channel ( Figure S13) containing lattice DMF and MeCN molecules which are stabilized by weak C16–H16···O3(2.511(1) Å; H16···O3) and nonclassical C27–H27c···I1–Cu1 (3.038(1) Å; H27c···I1) H-bonding interactions (). The pyridyl and anisole rings of ligands are slipped at a distance of 4.782 Å over each other, and the anisole rings are slightly tilted to facilitate the interdigitation. Topological investigation of 1 reveals it is sql/Shubnikov tetragonal plane net topology with Schlafli symbol of {44.62} ( Figure S14). TGA ( Figure S7) shows a weight loss of ∼10.6% (calcd, ∼11.1%) in the temperature range of 150–180 °C due to loss of two lattice DMF and one MeCN molecule and reveals its stability up to 380 °C. The bulk phase PXRD patterns of 1 ( Figure S8) is in good agreement with the simulated one based on the SCXRD data, which indicates the phase purity of the as-synthesized product. Further, in order to ensure the stability of the desolvated framework, 1 was treated at 150 °C under vacuum for 24 h and the sample 1′ shows loss of the lattice DMF and MeCN molecules in TGA (). PXRD analysis demonstrates that it retains its framework stability ( Figures S1 and S2) after loss of the lattice solvent molecules. The calculated free volume in 1′ is 26.7% (total potential solvent area volume 1333.7 Å3 per unit cell volume 5001.9 Å3), obtained by PLATON analysis. The porosity was also confirmed by N2, CO2, and CH4 sorption analysis at 77, 195, 273, and 298 K ( Figures S15 and S16). It was observed that on exposure to open atmosphere complex 1 shows rapid color change from orange (b) to brown (1a) (a) in few minutes but retains its crystallinity. TGA of 1a indicates a weight loss of 11.6% (calcd, 11.9%) in the temperature range of 150–200 °C that corresponds to the loss of two DMF and one H2O molecule ( Figure S1). The overall framework structure of 1a is similar to that of 1 except replacement of one MeCN with H2O molecule ([Cu­(L)­(I)]2n ·2nDMF·nH2O; 1a) (). In addition, it has been found that the anisole ring of ligand L was tilted at an angle of 21.59° with respect to its central pyridine ring, and the angle is slightly less (0.53°) compared to that of complex 1. The encapsulated H2O in 1a is stabilized by H-bonding interactions with lattice DMF molecule (O3···O7 = 2.303(1) Å) (a). Along the c-axis, it has been observed that a column of water molecules is sandwiched between the columns of DMF molecules ( Figure S17). The distance between the two nearest DMF molecules is 8.978 Å whereas the distance between two nearest water molecules is 8.964 Å. It is worth noting that in comparison to 1, in 1a the distance between two DMF columns is widened by 2.462 Å which might be because of the intervening water columns between two DMF columns. But it is surprising that the calculated solvent accessible volume of the desolvated framework of 1a is the same as that of 1 which signifies the adaptability of the framework to all types of the guest without any structural transformation. PXRD analysis of 1a supports the framework stability even after the accumulation of one water molecule by replacing one MeCN molecule. Further, single crystals of 1 were exposed to different solvent vapors, namely, DMSO, MeOH, and MeCN at RT which lead to the exchange of lattice solvent molecules in a SCSC fashion and yield complexes, namely, 1b, 1c, and 1d (, Tables S1 and S3) and exhibit unique colors which can be visually differentiated (). PXRD analysis reveals bulk phase purity, and elemental analysis confirms the elemental composition of the solvent exchanged complexes ( Figure S8). When single crystals of 1 were exposed to the vapor of a mixture of DMSO/MeOH/MeCN (volume ratio, 1:1:1), the framework selectively encapsulated DMSO (). Noncovalent interactions between the entrapped solvent molecules (a,c) and the polar environment of the channels within the framework as well as the appropriate size, shape, and polarity of the solvent molecules (polarity, DMSO > MeCN > DMF > MeOH) are likely to be responsible for the selective encapsulation.

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure and Transformations

CuI was chosen as a precursor for its diverse photophysical properties, so it was expected to show guest responsive luminescence properties. SCXRD analysis ( Tables S1-S3) reveals that 1 crystallizes in a monoclinic system with C2/c space group. Each Cu(I) center in 1 is coordinated by N atoms of two ligands (L) and two iodide ions resulting a distorted tetrahedral geometry ( Figure S9). The measured Cu-N distance is 2.020(7) Å, and Cu-I distances are 2.664(1) and 2.669(1) Å, respectively. The bond angles around the Cu(I) center lies in the range of 100.70(5)-121.75(5)°. The distortion from the regular tetrahedral geometry can be described by an angular index (τ4), which was defined by Houser and co-workers as follows: τ4 = [360 - (a + b)]/141 (a and b are the two largest angles around a four-coordinate metal center). Since, in 1, the calculated τ4 = 0.87, the coordination geometry around the Cu(I) center can be best described as trigonal pyramidal. Besides, it exhibits a rhomboidal Cu2I2 core, which can be termed as a secondary building unit (SBU; a). The repetition of the [(CuI)2(L)2] units give rise to an extended 2D 44 (brick-like) net ( Figure S10). In the Cu2I2 core, the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance is 2.596(2) Å and Cu-I-Cu and I-Cu-I bond angles are 58.24(4)° and 121.75(5)°, respectively. Interestingly, four rhomboidal Cu2I2 units are connected through four ligands to form a [4 + 4] metallamacrocylic unit ( Figure S11), and the distances between the centroid of the Cu2I2 units connected by ligand L are in the range of 13.332-13.479 Å. Further, the 2D 44 nets are interdigitated (c) with each other to form a supramolecular 3D MOF (d). The interdigitated layers are stabilized by π⋅⋅⋅π interactions among the pyridyl rings of L and CH⋅⋅⋅π interaction between methoxy group and pyridyl ring of L (). Complex 1 also exhibits rectangular voids of dimension 7.67 Å × 9.18 Å down the c-axis ( Figure S12). Detailed study of one rectangular void reveals the presence of a 1D channel ( Figure S13) containing lattice DMF and MeCN molecules which are stabilized by weak C16-H16⋅⋅⋅O3(2.511(1) Å; H16⋅⋅⋅O3) and nonclassical C27-H27c⋅⋅⋅I1-Cu1 (3.038(1) Å; H27c⋅⋅⋅I1) H-bonding interactions (). The pyridyl and anisole rings of ligands are slipped at a distance of 4.782 Å over each other, and the anisole rings are slightly tilted to facilitate the interdigitation. Topological investigation of 1 reveals it is sql/Shubnikov tetragonal plane net topology with Schlafli symbol of {44.62} ( Figure S14). TGA ( Figure S7) shows a weight loss of ~10.6% (calcd, ~11.1%) in the temperature range of 150-180 °C due to loss of two lattice DMF and one MeCN molecule and reveals its stability up to 380 °C. The bulk phase PXRD patterns of 1 ( Figure S8) is in good agreement with the simulated one based on the SCXRD data, which indicates the phase purity of the as-synthesized product. Further, in order to ensure the stability of the desolvated framework, 1 was treated at 150 °C under vacuum for 24 h and the sample 1' shows loss of the lattice DMF and MeCN molecules in TGA (). PXRD analysis demonstrates that it retains its framework stability ( Figures S1 and S2) after loss of the lattice solvent molecules. The calculated free volume in 1' is 26.7% (total potential solvent area volume 1333.7 Å3 per unit cell volume 5001.9 Å3), obtained by PLATON analysis. The porosity was also confirmed by N2, CO2, and CH4 sorption analysis at 77, 195, 273, and 298 K ( Figures S15 and S16). It was observed that on exposure to open atmosphere complex 1 shows rapid color change from orange (b) to brown (1a) (a) in few minutes but retains its crystallinity. TGA of 1a indicates a weight loss of 11.6% (calcd, 11.9%) in the temperature range of 150-200 °C that corresponds to the loss of two DMF and one H2O molecule ( Figure S1). The overall framework structure of 1a is similar to that of 1 except replacement of one MeCN with H2O molecule ([Cu(L)(I)]2n ⋅2nDMF⋅nH2O; 1a) (). In addition, it has been found that the anisole ring of ligand L was tilted at an angle of 21.59° with respect to its central pyridine ring, and the angle is slightly less (0.53°) compared to that of complex 1. The encapsulated H2O in 1a is stabilized by H-bonding interactions with lattice DMF molecule (O3⋅⋅⋅O7 = 2.303(1) Å) (a). Along the c-axis, it has been observed that a column of water molecules is sandwiched between the columns of DMF molecules ( Figure S17). The distance between the two nearest DMF molecules is 8.978 Å whereas the distance between two nearest water molecules is 8.964 Å. It is worth noting that in comparison to 1, in 1a the distance between two DMF columns is widened by 2.462 Å which might be because of the intervening water columns between two DMF columns. But it is surprising that the calculated solvent accessible volume of the desolvated framework of 1a is the same as that of 1 which signifies the adaptability of the framework to all types of the guest without any structural transformation. PXRD analysis of 1a supports the framework stability even after the accumulation of one water molecule by replacing one MeCN molecule. Further, single crystals of 1 were exposed to different solvent vapors, namely, DMSO, MeOH, and MeCN at RT which lead to the exchange of lattice solvent molecules in a SCSC fashion and yield complexes, namely, 1b, 1c, and 1d (,  Tables S1 and S3) and exhibit unique colors which can be visually differentiated (). PXRD analysis reveals bulk phase purity, and elemental analysis confirms the elemental composition of the solvent exchanged complexes ( Figure S8). When single crystals of 1 were exposed to the vapor of a mixture of DMSO/MeOH/MeCN (volume ratio, 1:1:1), the framework selectively encapsulated DMSO (). Noncovalent interactions between the entrapped solvent molecules (a,c) and the polar environment of the channels within the framework as well as the appropriate size, shape, and polarity of the solvent molecules (polarity, DMSO > MeCN > DMF > MeOH) are likely to be responsible for the selective encapsulation.

elements.content: Detailed structural analysis revealed that C–H···π interactions between one of the pyridyl rings of the ligand (L) and methyl hydrogen of DMSO, one C–H···I H-bonding between the Cu2I2 core and methyl hydrogen of DMSO, C–H···O H-bonding interactions among DMSO guest molecules, and one C–H···O H-bonding interaction between DMSO and L (b) play an important role in selective encapsulation. Reversibility of the encapsulation processes was also confirmed by the experiments as described in the (Scheme S1, Figure S18). Furthermore, crystals of 1 were exposed to harmful halogenated aromatics such as monohalobenzene vapors (Ph–F, Ph–Cl, Ph–Br, and Ph–I) at RT for encapsulation. Interestingly, in this case also the lattice DMF and MeCN molecules in 1 are replaced to yield the corresponding guest included complexes, namely, 1e, 1f, 1g, and 1h ( and Tables S1and S3) in the SCSC manner with distinct color changes (). The test confirmed the reversible inclusion and exclusion for all halobenzenes (details in the , Scheme S2 and Figure S19) and selectivity of 1 toward Ph–Cl (). The polarity of Ph–Cl (Ph–Cl > Ph–F > Ph–Br > Ph–I) is likely to be responsible for its selective encapsulation among others. Several weak interactions such as C–H···π (operating between the pyridyl rings of L and Ph–Cl) and C–H···I H-bonding (between the Cu2I2 core and Ph–Cl) are responsible for stabilization of the incorporated Ph–Cl molecule inside the pores (a–c). The Ph–Cl molecules are arranged in an antiparallel fashion to facilitate dipole–dipole interactions in the 1D channel. In another set of experiments, single crystals of 1 were exposed to vapors of N-heterocyclic compounds such as py, trz (0.001 mmol/mL MeCN solution) and aliphatic amine such as dea at RT and the corresponding guest included complexes, namely, 1i, 1j, and 1k ( and Tables S1 and S3) were obtained with retention of single crystallinity and having a distinct color in each case (). Test results showed the selectivity of 1 toward pyridine (), and the reversibility of encapsulation was also confirmed as before ( Scheme S3 and Figure S20). The different polarity of amines (py > dea > trz) are responsible for the selectivity. Strong CC···H–C π-interaction between partially eclipsed pyridine moieties, two strong C–H···I H-bondings (between cluster-centered core (Cu2I2) and py), two intra py CH···N H-bondings and two CH···N H-bondings between pyridine and L provide extra stability to py inside the channels (a). Finally, single crystals of 1 were also exposed to vapors of explosives such as NB and other nitroaromatics such as 1,2-DNB, 1,3-DNB, 1,4-DNB, Cl-DNB , and TNP (DNB = dinitrobenzene and TNP = 2,4,6-trinitrophenol in MeCN solutions (0.001 mmol/mL) with distinct color changes (b and ). Interestingly, two nitrobenzene included complexes, namely, 1l and 1m, were obtained with retention of single crystallinity ( and Tables S1 and S3). The test showed the selective trapping of more polar NB among other nitroaromatics (). Various weak interactions such as π···π interactions between one of the pyridyl ring of L and NB, π···π interactions between NB moieties, two intra NB CH···O H-bondings (which hold them together inside the channel), and two C–H···I H-bondings between cluster-centered core (Cu2I2) and NB are observed (a). Like others, inclusion and exclusion of guest nitrobenzene molecules are reversible (details in Scheme S4 and Figure S21).

elements.content: In fluorescence measurements, 1 exhibits a typical red emission band at λem = 728 nm upon excitation at λex = 418 nm ( Figure S22) and that is the characteristic of a Cu2I2 core, near the IR region and independent of the ligand. The band can be assigned to mixed iodide (I) to Cu­(I) charge transfer (XMCT where X = I) and [3d→4s/4p] Cu2I2 core-centered transition. The emission maxima of different solvents contained in Cu­(I)­MOF and monohalobenzene contained in Cu­(I)­MOF at 298 K are blue-shifted (a,b) and show a negative solvatochromic effect (for solvents) which is due to the different polarity of the solvents and monohalobenzenes. The hypsochromic shift (blue shift) implies that the excited state dipole moment is greater than that of the ground state in 1. With a decrease in polarity of the guests, the core-centered excited state of the Cu­(I) MOF is expected to be destabilized more and that causes the blue shift. The observed difference in luminescence behavior of 1 toward polar protic and polar aprotic solvents contained in Cu­(I)­MOF can also be ascribed to the different H-bonding abilities of the solvents. Although, MeOH is the least polar, the emission maximum is observed at higher wavelength compared to other solvents, due to its pronounced H-bonding interactions with 1 (c) and that seems to stabilize the core-centered excited state. Compared to solvents, the extent of the blue shift is less for the monohalobenzenes because of comparatively more stabilization of the core-centered excited state of the MOF. For N-heterocycles and amine contained in Cu­(I)­MOF, solid state fluorescence study reveals that the blue shift is comparable with the solvents, and the observed difference in emission maxima of the encapsulated MOF (c) is likely dominated by the different polarities of these species. Because py is more polar among the considered N-heterocycles and amines, the emission maximum is expected to be less blue-shifted, but the π-acceptor character of py destabilizes the core-centered transition due to C–H···I H-bonding between the Cu2I2 core and py (a–c). Overall, in the presence of guest molecules the extent of the blue shift is ∼100–200 nm that is appreciably high and comparable to very few literature reports known.
elements.clean_text:
Solid State Fluorescence Study

In fluorescence measurements, 1 exhibits a typical red emission band at λem = 728 nm upon excitation at λex = 418 nm ( Figure S22) and that is the characteristic of a Cu2I2 core, near the IR region and independent of the ligand. The band can be assigned to mixed iodide (I) to Cu(I) charge transfer (XMCT where X = I) and [3d→4s/4p] Cu2I2 core-centered transition. The emission maxima of different solvents contained in Cu(I)MOF and monohalobenzene contained in Cu(I)MOF at 298 K are blue-shifted (a,b) and show a negative solvatochromic effect (for solvents) which is due to the different polarity of the solvents and monohalobenzenes. The hypsochromic shift (blue shift) implies that the excited state dipole moment is greater than that of the ground state in 1. With a decrease in polarity of the guests, the core-centered excited state of the Cu(I) MOF is expected to be destabilized more and that causes the blue shift. The observed difference in luminescence behavior of 1 toward polar protic and polar aprotic solvents contained in Cu(I)MOF can also be ascribed to the different H-bonding abilities of the solvents. Although, MeOH is the least polar, the emission maximum is observed at higher wavelength compared to other solvents, due to its pronounced H-bonding interactions with 1 (c) and that seems to stabilize the core-centered excited state. Compared to solvents, the extent of the blue shift is less for the monohalobenzenes because of comparatively more stabilization of the core-centered excited state of the MOF. For N-heterocycles and amine contained in Cu(I)MOF, solid state fluorescence study reveals that the blue shift is comparable with the solvents, and the observed difference in emission maxima of the encapsulated MOF (c) is likely dominated by the different polarities of these species. Because py is more polar among the considered N-heterocycles and amines, the emission maximum is expected to be less blue-shifted, but the π-acceptor character of py destabilizes the core-centered transition due to C-H⋅⋅⋅I H-bonding between the Cu2I2 core and py (a-c). Overall, in the presence of guest molecules the extent of the blue shift is ~100-200 nm that is appreciably high and comparable to very few literature reports known.

elements.clean_text:
Quantitative Detection by Fluorescence Quenching Effect

To explore the ability of 1 to detect trace quantities of N-heterocycles and amine, solution phase fluorescence experiments were performed. The PXRD patterns of 1 in different analytes show that the framework remains stable during fluorescence titrations ( Figure S23).

elements.content: With increasing concentration of analytes, rapid fluorescence quenching was observed (a and Figure S24) for 1 in MeCN solution (1 mg/mL). The quenching efficiency (b) and quenching constant of the analytes were determined using the Stern–Volmer equation (SV); I 0/I) = K SV[A] + 1, where I 0 and I are the fluorescence intensities before and after addition of the respective analytes, [A] is the molar concentration of the analyte, and K SV is the quenching constant (M–1). The fluorescence quenching of 1 follows SV behavior in the concentration range of 0–200 μL.

The quenching efficiency (b) and quenching constant of the analytes were determined using the Stern-Volmer equation (SV); I 0/I) = K SV[A] + 1, where I 0 and I are the fluorescence intensities before and after addition of the respective analytes, [A] is the molar concentration of the analyte, and K SV is the quenching constant (M-1). The fluorescence quenching of 1 follows SV behavior in the concentration range of 0-200 μL.

elements.content: Among the analytes, dea exhibits the highest quenching efficiency of 36% with a SV constant of 9.5 × 103 M–1, which is comparable to similar reported systems, and the linear nature of SV plots (c) signifies the dynamic nature of quenching. The decrease in fluorescence signal depends on H-bonding interactions between the analytes and 1, and the interactions are more for dea compared to trz and py and that is evident from the occurrence of low emissive excited state charge transfer via proton transfer. Further, in order to check the ability of 1 to detect trace quantities of nitroaromatics, fluorescence quenching titrations were performed with the incremental addition of the nitroaromatic analytes dispersed in MeCN solvent (a and Figures S25–S29). The PXRD patterns confirm that the complexes remain stable even after fluorescence titrations with different analytes ( Figure S30). The highest fluorescence quenching of 65% was observed (b) upon incremental addition (0–200 μL) of a TNP solution, and the detection limit was found to be 0.0066 mM. On the other hand, all other nitro compounds show little effect on the fluorescence intensity and illustrate the high selectivity of 1 for TNP. The SV plot for TNP was observed to be nonlinear at higher concentrations whereas for all other nitro compounds it is linear (c). The nonlinearity of SV plot for TNP can be ascribed to self-absorption or energy transfer process. The K SV for TNP was found to be 2.9 × 104 M–1, which is comparable to reported organic polymers and MOFs ( Table S4). But the value is much higher than those of other nitroaromatic analytes and signifies the best quenching ability. In order to check the selectivity of 1 toward TNP, emission properties of 1 were recorded in the presence of other nitroaromatic analytes dispersed in MeCN. It was observed that even in the presence of equal concentrations of other analytes the quenching of TNP remains unaffected (d) and this establishes the exceptional selectivity of 1 toward TNP even in the presence of competing nitroaromatics in MeCN. In this context, understanding the underlying mechanism for fluorescence quenching is of utmost important to know the origin of the high selectivity of 1 toward TNP. It is known that the conduction band (CB) of a MOF lies at higher energies than the LUMOs of nitroaromatic analytes, and this drives electron transfer phenomenon from the CB of the MOF to the electron deficient analytes, thus resulting in fluorescence quenching. In this case, the maximum fluorescence quenching for TNP compared to other analytes is likely due to the lower LUMO energy of TNP as is evident from literature reports. Furthermore, from the nonlinear nature of the SV plot for TNP, it can be speculated that the fluorescence quenching occurs due to a resonance energy transfer mechanism, which can be attributed to the confinement of analytes in the pores keeping the MOF and analytes in close proximity to each other. The phenomenon was further confirmed by the observation of maximum spectral overlap between the absorption spectrum of TNP and emission spectrum of MOF 1 (e). For all of the other analytes, the overlap was negligible. Thus, it is clear that both electron and long-range energy transfer processes are responsible for efficient fluorescence quenching by TNP in contrast to other nitro analytes.

elements.content: In summary a 2D Cu­(I)-based MOF has been synthesized which seems to be the first report of any material which reversibly encapsulates solvents, toxic monohalobenzenes, N-heterocycles, amine, and explosive nitroaromatics in vapor phase under ambient conditions without loss of framework integrity. More interestingly, MOF 1 displays unique colors upon guest encapsulation and can be considered as a universal naked eye detector for small molecules. The results represent a critical step toward the design of MOFs having high stability, selectivity, and reversibility.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary a 2D Cu(I)-based MOF has been synthesized which seems to be the first report of any material which reversibly encapsulates solvents, toxic monohalobenzenes, N-heterocycles, amine, and explosive nitroaromatics in vapor phase under ambient conditions without loss of framework integrity. More interestingly, MOF 1 displays unique colors upon guest encapsulation and can be considered as a universal naked eye detector for small molecules. The results represent a critical step toward the design of MOFs having high stability, selectivity, and reversibility.

elements.content: All the reagents and solvents used were commercially available and used as obtained. 4-Methoxybenzaldehyde, 4-acetylpyridine, copper iodide (CuI), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), chlorobenzene (Ph–Cl), 1,2-dinitrobenzene (1,2-DNB), and 1,4-dinitrobenzene (1,4-DNB) were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich Chemicals Co. All other chemicals were obtained from Spectrochem Pvt. Ltd. The elemental analyses were performed on an Elementar Micro vario Cube elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectra (400–4000 cm–1) were recorded on KBr pellets with a PerkinElmer Spectrum BX spectrometer. TGA measurements were conducted on a PerkinElmer thermogravimetric analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in the temperature range of 30–600 °C. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a PANalytical EMPYREAN instrument using Cu Kα radiation. Gas sorption studies were performed on a BELSORP MAX (BEL JAPAN) volumetric adsorption analyzer. Absorption studies were recorded on a Cary 100 UV–vis spectrophotometer. All of the solid phase and solution phase fluorescence measurements were recorded on a HORIBA JOBINYVON FLUOROLOG-4 spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All the reagents and solvents used were commercially available and used as obtained. 4-Methoxybenzaldehyde, 4-acetylpyridine, copper iodide (CuI), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), chlorobenzene (Ph-Cl), 1,2-dinitrobenzene (1,2-DNB), and 1,4-dinitrobenzene (1,4-DNB) were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich Chemicals Co. All other chemicals were obtained from Spectrochem Pvt. Ltd. The elemental analyses were performed on an Elementar Micro vario Cube elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectra (400-4000 cm-1) were recorded on KBr pellets with a PerkinElmer Spectrum BX spectrometer. TGA measurements were conducted on a PerkinElmer thermogravimetric analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in the temperature range of 30-600 °C. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a PANalytical EMPYREAN instrument using Cu Kα radiation. Gas sorption studies were performed on a BELSORP MAX (BEL JAPAN) volumetric adsorption analyzer. Absorption studies were recorded on a Cary 100 UV-vis spectrophotometer. All of the solid phase and solution phase fluorescence measurements were recorded on a HORIBA JOBINYVON FLUOROLOG-4 spectrophotometer.

elements.clean_text:
Syntheses

4'-(4-Methoxyphenyl)-4,2':6',4"-terpyridine (L)

KOH beads (16.04 mmol, 1 g) were added to 60 mL of MeOH solution of 4-acetylpyridine (16.53 mmol, 2 g) under vigorous stirring in a 250 mL round-bottom flask. To this solution, 4-methoxybenzaldehyde (8.24 mmol, 1.12 g) was added. After a yellowish color had developed, 60 mL of aqueous NH3 (25%) was added immediately to the solution and stirred for 3 days. The resulting white precipitate was filtered, washed with water, and recrystallized from CHCl3. Yield: 32.5% based on 4-methoxybenzaldehyde; mp 228 °C.

elements.content: In a typical hydrothermal synthesis, CuI (0.1 mmol, 19 mg) and excess KI (5 times of CuI, 0.5 mmol, 95 mg) were dissolved in 6 mL of mixed solvent (MeCN and DMF; volume ratio, 1:1). To this mixture, L (0.05 mmol, 16.0 mg) was added and stirred for 10 min. Thereafter, the whole mixture was transferred into a 15 mL closed Teflon lined steel vessel and kept in oven for 3 days at 140 °C. After 3 days, orange block shaped single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were collected by filtration, washed with MeCN several times, and dried in air. Yield: 64%. FT-IR (KBr pellet, 400–4000 cm–1): 3453, 2375, 2256, 1659, 1600, 1516, 1462, 1396, 1292, 1244, 1181, 1091, 1058, 1025, 886, 826, 671, 643, 572, 523. Elem. Anal. cln_elements.clean_text:
Syntheses

4'-(4-Methoxyphenyl)-4,2':6',4"-terpyridine (L)

KOH beads (16.04 mmol, 1 g) were added to 60 mL of MeOH solution of 4-acetylpyridine (16.53 mmol, 2 g) under vigorous stirring in a 250 mL round-bottom flask. To this solution, 4-methoxybenzaldehyde (8.24 mmol, 1.12 g) was added. After a yellowish color had developed, 60 mL of aqueous NH3 (25%) was added immediately to the solution and stirred for 3 days. The resulting white precipitate was filtered, washed with water, and recrystallized from CHCl3. Yield: 32.5% based on 4-methoxybenzaldehyde; mp 228 °C. 

[Cu(L)(I)]2n ⋅2nDMF⋅nMeCN (1)

In a typical hydrothermal synthesis, CuI (0.1 mmol, 19 mg) and excess KI (5 times of CuI, 0.5 mmol, 95 mg) were dissolved in 6 mL of mixed solvent (MeCN and DMF; volume ratio, 1:1). To this mixture, L (0.05 mmol, 16.0 mg) was added and stirred for 10 min. Thereafter, the whole mixture was transferred into a 15 mL closed Teflon lined steel vessel and kept in oven for 3 days at 140 °C. After 3 days, orange block shaped single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were collected by filtration, washed with MeCN several times, and dried in air. Yield: 64%. FT-IR (KBr pellet, 400-4000 cm-1): 3453, 2375, 2256, 1659, 1600, 1516, 1462, 1396, 1292, 1244, 1181, 1091, 1058, 1025, 886, 826, 671, 643, 572, 523. Elem. Anal. Calcd (%): C, 50.13; H, 3.81; N, 11.03. Found (%): C, 49.76; H, 3.35; N, 10.69.

[Cu(L)(I)] n ⋅nDMSO (1b)

Crystals (100 mg) of 1 were placed in small (5 mL) open glass vials, and those were placed into capped glass vials (20 mL) containing 2 mL of DMSO for 7 days to ensure that the equilibrated vapor pressure of DMSO was reached. DMSO exchanged crystals (1b) suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained after 7 days. FT-IR (KBr pellet, 400-4000 cm-1): 3443, 3351, 3252, 2375, 1608, 1519, 1461, 1400, 1295, 1243, 1184, 1112, 1056, 1024, 1015, 948, 886, 827, 672, 643, 571, 524. Elem. Anal. Calcd (%): C, 47.41; H, 3.81; N, 6.91; S, 5.27. Found (%): C, 47.26; H, 3.59; N, 6.71; S, 5.07.

[Cu(L)(I)] n ⋅2nMeOH (1c)

The same procedure as that for 1b was employed but instead of DMSO, 2 mL of dry MeOH was used. MeOH exchanged crystals (1c) suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained almost after 7 days. FT-IR (KBr pellet, 400-4000 cm-1): 3443, 2371, 1600, 1563, 1542, 1516, 1461, 1400, 1344, 1295, 1240, 1184, 1118, 1062, 1027, 885, 827, 707, 675, 643, 571, 524. Elem. Anal. Calcd (%): C, 48.87; H, 3.59; N, 7.12. Found (%): C, 48.62; H, 3.39; N, 6.78.

[Cu(L)(I)]2n ⋅n(Ph-Cl) (1f)

The same procedure as that for 1b was employed, but 2 mL of Ph-Cl solvent was used. FT-IR (KBr pellet, 400-4000 cm-1): 3453, 2374, 1605, 1516, 1461, 1398, 1295, 1243, 1180, 1092, 1113, 1025, 882, 825, 741, 674, 637, 571, 523. Elem. Anal. Calcd (%): C, 51.27; H, 3.27; N, 7.18. Found (%): C, 51.02; H, 3.05; N, 6.87.
